reasoning: The question targets a central hinge in the paper’s optimistic path (partial AM-convergence + trade): whether enough independent power-holders exist for bargaining/representation to matter. A strong answer would materially redirect strategy between (i) elite-targeted interventions vs (ii) scalable bargaining/anti-threat institutions, so cruciality and decision hook are high. It is fairly paper-specific because it operationalises the paper’s ‘concentration of power’ blocker for the trade-based route to mostly-great futures, though power-concentration questions also arise in broader AI governance (so not maximal specificity). Tractability is moderate: one can make progress via political-economy/IO models, compute supply-chain and deployment chokepoint analysis, ownership/governance mapping, and scenario-based forecasting, but “post-AGI” regimes, endogeneity, and strategic behavior make definitive estimation hard. Clarity is decent but not perfect: ‘effective number of decisive actors’ and the thresholds (10–100 vs 1,000+) need tighter definition (decisive over what decisions? over what time window? global vs regional vs sectoral). Dead weight is low; most text sharpens the hinge and measurement approaches.
title: Post-AGI power concentration and viability of pluralist governance
